newsitem.title: UK: Olivetti PC sale delights UK institution.
newsitem.headline: Olivetti PC sale delights UK institution.

text.p: An institutional investor in Olivetti said on Tuesday he was delighted the Italian technology company had agreed to sell its loss-making personal computer division, which he said had been "haemorrhaging cash".
"I'm just delighted they've got rid of the business and seem to have got a very good price for it," Talal Shakerchi, head of European equities at London-based fund managers Old Mutual, told Reuters.
Shakerchi says that according to his valuation, Olivetti shares should be worth 1,600 lire each -- a far cry from their trading level on Tuesday of around 675 lire.
Old Mutual, which has a stake of just under two percent of Olivetti, was one of the institutional investors who consistently urged the company to sell the ailing PC division.
"As long as you've got a company in the group which is destroying value, nobody is going to be willing to pay full value for the assets because they are being destroyed over time," Shakerchi said.
Olivetti announced on Monday that it would get 250-300 billion lire from the sale to a new company called Piedmont, in which mysterious U.S. financier Edward Gottesman has a stake.

Old Mutual's confidence in Olivetti's management has been boosted since the group's new chief executive Roberto Colaninno started delivering on his short-term promises -- such as the sale of the division.

It now hopes Colaninno will see his long-term aims realised. The institution is waiting to see a better control of working capital and Olivetti's businesses having a positive cash flow by the end of the year, Shakerchi said.
Other fund managers such as Baring Asset Management either declined comment on the sale or were not immediately available. -- Kirstin Ridley, London Newsroom +44 171 542 7987
